$values.title: Money and benefits
$values.text: Help with money when you leave care and benefits you can apply for

$values.value: Help with money and benefits you can apply for
Care leaver support
Support you might get if you have been in care or ‘looked after’
Help with money
Leaving Care Allowance
Money to set up your next home (also called ‘Setting Up Home Allowance’)
Junior Individual Savings Account (ISA) (Opens in a new tab)
A bank account containing money you can get from your 18th birthday
Higher Education Bursary
Money to help you go to university or college
Apprenticeships Care Leavers’ Bursary (Opens in a new tab)
Money to help you if you're doing an apprenticeship
Managing your money
Personal adviser (PA)
Someone who guides you on how to manage your money and helps you get support
Pathway Plan
A plan you make with your PA that covers how to manage your money and get support you need
Local support
You might get support from your local council’s Local Offer for care leavers
For example, this could include things like:
money for your birthday
help paying for your driving lessons or driving test
money for living costs to cover food, travel and essential clothes
Find out more about Local Offers
More support
Support that your personal adviser can help you apply for:
Universal Credit (Opens in a new tab)
A payment to help you with living costs if you’re on a low income, out of work or cannot work.
Personal Independence Payment (PIP) (Opens in a new tab)
To help you with living costs if you have a disability, illness or health condition and difficulties with daily living or mobility.
Discretionary Housing Payment (DHP) (Opens in a new tab)
A payment to help you with rent or housing costs.
Council tax support (Opens in a new tab)
Apply to your local council for a reduction on your council tax bill.

$values.title: Housing and accommodation
$values.text: Help finding somewhere to live and other support with housing costs

$values.value: Help with housing costs and finding somewhere to live
Care leaver support
Support you might get if you have been in care or ‘looked after’
Help with money
Leaving Care Allowance
Money to set up your next home (also called ‘Setting Up Home Allowance’)
Junior Individual Savings Account (ISA) (Opens in a new tab)
A bank account containing money you can get from your 18th birthday
Planning where you’ll live
Personal adviser (PA)
Someone who helps you find somewhere safe to live that meets your needs
Pathway Plan
A plan you make with your PA that covers where you will live, including support you need
Local support
You might get support from your local council’s Local Offer for care leavers
For example, this could include things like:
money off your council tax bill (council tax discount) or not paying it at all (council tax exemption)
acting as a guarantor for rent so you can live in private rented property or help with a deposit
help with housing costs like a TV licence (making you exempt from the fee), internet or utility bills (gas, electricity and water)
Find out more about Local Offers
More support
Support that your personal adviser can help you apply for:
Universal Credit (Opens in a new tab)
A payment to help you with living costs if you’re on a low income, out of work or cannot work.
Discretionary Housing Payment (DHP) (Opens in a new tab)
A payment to help you with rent or housing costs.
Council tax support (Opens in a new tab)
Apply to your local council for a reduction on your council tax bill.

$values.title: Work and employment
$values.text: Support and services to help with finding and staying in work

$values.value: Support and services to help with finding and staying in work
Care leaver support
Support you might get if you have been in care or ‘looked after’
Planning your career
Personal adviser (PA)
Someone who helps you plan your career or find and stay in work
Pathway Plan
A plan you make with your PA that covers work and career goals, including support you need
Finding work or training
Apprenticeships Care Leavers’ Bursary (Opens in a new tab)
Money to help you if you're doing an apprenticeship
Care Leaver Covenant (Opens in a new tab)
Opportunities and offers for care leavers, including jobs, apprenticeships and discounts
Civil Service Care Leavers Internship Scheme (Opens in a new tab)
Scheme offering care leavers an 18-month paid internship in UK government
Local support
You might get support from your local council’s Local Offer for care leavers
For example, this could include things like:
help with travel costs (like a bus pass) or essential clothes for work or interviews
careers advice and guidance, such as help with job searches or writing your CV
work experience or an apprenticeship at your council
Find out more about Local Offers
More support
Support that your personal adviser can help you apply for:
Access to Work (Opens in a new tab)
To help get you into or stay in work if you have a physical or mental health condition or disability.
Universal Credit (Opens in a new tab)
A payment to help you with living costs if you’re on a low income, out of work or cannot work.
Reasonable adjustment (Opens in a new tab)
Adjustments employers must make for people with a disability, illness or health condition.
Work and health programme (Opens in a new tab)
Help finding and keeping a job if you’re out of work.

$values.title: Education and training
$values.text: Support to help you start or continue education and training

$values.value: Help with costs and making plans to do a course or training
Care leaver support
Support you might get if you have been in care or ‘looked after’
Help with money
Higher Education Bursary
Money to help you go to university or college
Apprenticeships Care Leavers’ Bursary (Opens in a new tab)
Money to help you if you're doing an apprenticeship
Planning your future
Personal adviser (PA)
Someone who helps you plan and make decisions around education and training
Pathway Plan
A plan you make with your PA that covers goals around education and training, including support you need
Finding a course or training
Care Leaver Covenant (Opens in a new tab)
Opportunities and offers for care leavers, including jobs, apprenticeships and discounts
Civil Service Care Leavers Internship Scheme (Opens in a new tab)
Scheme offering care leavers an 18-month paid internship in UK government
Local support
You might get support from your local council’s Local Offer for care leavers
For example, this could include things like:
help with travel costs (like a bus pass), equipment or essential clothes
help with course fees or tutoring support
work experience or an apprenticeship at your council
Find out more about Local Offers
More support
Support that your personal adviser can help you apply for:
Student finance calculator (Opens in a new tab)
Work out what help you could get with the study costs as an undergraduate student.
16 to 19 bursary (Opens in a new tab)
To help you pay for education and training costs at school or college.
Extra money to pay for university (Opens in a new tab)
Money from your university or college on top of any other student finance.
Learner support (Opens in a new tab)
To help with the costs for things you need to attend a further education course, if you are aged 19 or older.

$values.title: Health and wellbeing
$values.text: Help with your physical and mental health, including disability support

$values.value: Support with your health, wellbeing and disability needs
Care leaver support
Support you might get if you have been in care or ‘looked after’
Help with your health
Personal adviser (PA)
Someone who helps you look after your health and wellbeing and finds you the right support
Pathway Plan
A plan you make with your PA that covers health and wellbeing support, including any specialist care or services
Care Leaver Covenant (Opens in a new tab)
Opportunities and offers for care leavers, including jobs, apprenticeships and discounts
Local support
You might get support from your local council’s Local Offer for care leavers
For example, this could include things like:
money for medication, the dentist or eyecare (like glasses or contact lenses)
mental health support like counselling
free or discounted membership for the gym or other leisure activities
Find out more about Local Offers
More support
Support that your personal adviser can help you apply for:
Personal Independence Payment (PIP) (Opens in a new tab)
To help you with living costs if you have a disability, illness or health condition and difficulties with daily living or mobility.
Access to Work (Opens in a new tab)
To help get you into or stay in work if you have a physical or mental health condition or disability.
Disabled students allowance (Opens in a new tab)
Help with extra support costs needed to study because you have a disability, illness or health condition.
Work and health programme (Opens in a new tab)
Help finding and keeping a job if you’re out of work.

$values.title: Unaccompanied asylum-seeking young people
$values.text: Help and advice if you arrived alone in the UK to seek asylum

link.title: Support for young people seeking asylum

$values.value: Find out about support, help and advice if you are a young asylum seeker.
Helpful links
Information, help and advice if you are an asylum seeker.
Claim asylum in the UK
How you must apply for asylum if you want to stay in the UK as a refugee.
Your asylum application
What happens when you claim asylum in the UK.
Statement of evidence form (SEF) completion instructions
Help filling in forms needed for your asylum claim.
Asylum applicants’ rights and responsibilities
Rights and responsibilities if you are applying for asylum in the UK.
Asylum support
Apply for housing and money if you are waiting for an asylum decision.
Appeal a decision by the immigration and asylum tribunal
How to appeal an asylum decision if you are not happy with it.
Find an immigration adviser
Find someone to give you advice about your asylum claim.
Legal aid
Apply for money to help with legal fees.
